cards.back:
X_k = (1/T₀) ∫_{T₀} x(t) e^{-jkω₀t} dt

Key: minus sign in exponent, 1/T₀ factor, integrate over one period.

x(t) = Σ_{k=-∞}^{∞} X_k e^{+jkω₀t}

Key: plus sign in exponent, no 1/T₀ factor, sum from -∞ to +∞.

cards.front: Why does the analysis integral extract only the k-th coefficient?
cards.back: Orthogonality: ∫_{T₀} e^{j(m-k)ω₀t} dt = 0 for m ≠ k, and = T₀ for m = k. So multiplying by e^{-jkω₀t} and integrating annihilates every term except X_k.

cards.front: What is X₀ and how do you compute it?
cards.back: X₀ = (1/T₀) ∫_{T₀} x(t) dt — the average (DC) value. The exponential disappears since e^{-j·0·t} = 1.

cards.front: Can you choose any interval to evaluate the FS integral?
cards.back: Yes — any contiguous interval of length T₀ gives the same X_k (due to periodicity). Choose the one that simplifies the integral. Common choices: [0, T₀] or [-T₀/2, +T₀/2].
|X_k| → 0 for any finite-power periodic signal. Higher harmonics carry less energy. This ensures the FS converges.
A ~9% overshoot near discontinuities when a periodic signal is approximated by a truncated FS. The overshoot persists (doesn't shrink) as more terms are added — it only gets narrower.

cards.front: What does conjugate symmetry X_{-k} = X_k* mean physically?
cards.back: For real signals: magnitudes are even symmetric (|X_{-k}| = |X_k|) and phases are odd anti-symmetric (∠X_{-k} = -∠X_k). This halves the independent information in the spectrum.

cards.front: What's the difference between the EFS and the Fourier Transform?
cards.back: EFS: for periodic signals, discrete spectrum (coefficients at kω₀). FT: for aperiodic signals, continuous spectrum X(ω). EFS sums from -∞ to +∞ over k; FT integrates from -∞ to +∞ over ω.

cards.front: What is the fundamental component and what are harmonics?
cards.back: X₁ is the fundamental (at ω₀). X_k for k ≥ 2 are harmonics: X₂ = 2nd harmonic (2ω₀), X₃ = 3rd harmonic (3ω₀), etc. Odd harmonics (3rd, 5th) are important in power systems for distortion analysis.
